questions.neutral: Is the whole city running hot today?

hobby.message: Is analog photography still worth the risk?
Still dodging towers with those drones?
Political literature age better than policy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: It feels like the whole city’s restless. Systems glitching, alarms echoing even in the restricted zones.
I collect old books—political ones, mostly. Not exactly encouraged these days.
Patrols came close to my block. Had to reorganize my shelves for safety.
Hard to focus with all the commotion outside.
It’s difficult to get anything done, even a bit of reading is a risk.
I restore banned political literature, quietly. Been at it for years.
Saw patrols making rounds again—this time for printed matter, not just tech.
Had to hide a few volumes last night. The air feels thin.
The city forgets, but paper remembers.
Hottest day yet—city on edge, systems stuttering, and it spills indoors too.
I collect and restore forbidden political books, if you can believe it.
Last week, searches swept my sector. They were after anything about those free zones.
It’s ironic—when order frays, old ideas return to relevance.
Had to move half my library into storage, just to be safe.
Passing the time reading feels strangely subversive now.
Stenograd’s always simmering, but today it’s a full boil—every corridor tense with rumors.
Most don’t know, but I collect old banned political manuals—restore them, sometimes recite passages.
Free zone simulations made authorities paranoid. Now even a pamphlet gets you scrutinized.
Had to inventory my whole collection, mark the riskiest ones—just routine for me.
Worked on restoring a pre-BCI manifesto last night, ink under my fingernails.
Feels like every page I read is a quiet protest against all this control.
Funny—my hobby, once history, is suddenly controversial again.
Today? The whole city’s burning with secrets—electrons and silence, rumors riding the blackout.
I restore and memorize banned works—manuals, speeches, documents scrubbed from the BCI’s record.
Started years ago; it’s the only honest history left in this place.
Once, that was just nostalgia. Now it feels dangerous. Free zone uprisings made print matter suspect again.
When Directorate squads swept my corridor, I camouflaged a shelf with Council-approved tomes.
One book—'Debate as Duty'—almost got me flagged; never thought I’d sweat over typesetting.
Sometimes I recite memory passages by candlelight, just to know they’re still alive.
Ironic, isn’t it? Their fear of ideas only sharpens their edge in my mind.
hobby_answer: Some literature does. Some belongs in the gutter.
Old pamphlets outlast half the Council's decrees.
It's a habit from before the Index, nothing more.
Suppression orders make collecting difficult lately.
That simulation nonsense has made books even riskier.
I'd say some political works survive policies, barely.
Censorship cycles make the old texts valuable—or dangerous.
My archive's discreet. After last week's patrols, discretion's survival.
Simulation leaks stir up old titles, not always by choice.
BCI falters, Directorate sniffs out 'contraband.' Hobby's never worse off.
Not much reading lately, just hiding.
Yes. Old tracts have outlasted every system, even this one.
I keep originals—marked, annotated, hidden.
Last Directorate order put my shelves in jeopardy.
Patrols hunting simulation chips almost swept past my door.
Now, reading at home feels like manning a checkpoint.
BCI outages make cataloguing risky business.
Strange—turning a page is now dissent.
Absolutely. Policy decays in months—good literature persists.
My collection is... unique—banned manifestos, Council speeches, conflicting doctrines.
Used to read nightly, faithfully.
After the simulation chip fiasco, Directorate combed for written subversion.
Saw the patrols outside, lights out, books hidden under floorboards.
Every footstep on the stairs, adrenaline. Had passages memorized in case.
Neighbors hiding too—old words suddenly currency.
Sometimes think that memory's the last archive we have left.
No contest. Literature is the memory systems try to erase.
Grew up copying illicit tracts by candlelight—before surveillance got everywhere.
My apartment’s shelves, annotated in margins, dog-eared from restless nights.
Recently, Directorate repression swept up books as well as chips—the old panic returns.
Spent hours silent, listening to boots on the landing...afraid they'd knock.
BCI scrambled access—my archive's tags betrayed me, almost cost everything.
Neighbors lost volumes—one had banned speeches burned in the garbage chute.
Never felt the line between reader and dissident so thin.
For all the system’s power, it can’t erase what I remember.
